examples package¶

Submodules¶

examples.doctest_example module¶

examples.doctest_example.testable(message)¶

A function with testable documentation

>>> testable('Hello you there')
'This was your message: Hello you there'

>>> for x in range(3):
...       print(x)
0
1
2
Parameters:message – any string
Returns:the string that was given as a parameter

examples.pep8_example module¶

Demonstrate PEP 8 layout

This module does nothing useful, aside from demonstrating most of the layout rules of PEP 8.

class examples.pep8_example.DorMouse¶

Bases: object

Tracks dormice, optionally associated with elephants.

Each DorMouse instance has the ability to associate with 0 or 1 Elephant instances. Use the set_elephant method to establish that association.

set_elephant(elephant)¶

Associate an Elephant with this DorMouse.

The elephant parameter must be an Elephant instance, or None. Setting the elephant to None breaks the association between this DorMouse and its Elephant.

class examples.pep8_example.Elephant(dormouse=None)¶

Bases: object

Tracks elephants and their optional associated dormice.

examples.pep8_example.ScarePair()¶

Create a ScarePair object linking an Elephant and a DorMouse.

Both the Elephant and the DorMouse instances of the pair are newly created. They are fully associated before the pair is returned.

examples.pep8_example.munge(left, right)¶

Make a horrible mess.

This function takes a pair of ScarePair objects and twists them up into a pretzel.

examples.sphinx_example module¶

examples.sphinx_example.docstring_example(foo, bar)¶

Munge foo and bar

Parameters:foo – should be an instance fo :class: ‘Twingy’ or

have a method equivalent to :meth: ‘Twingy.munge’ :param bar: will be passed as first parameter to :meth: ‘Twingy.munge’ :return:
